6mm double Rod Mount.
Just print, put the rod's, nuts and bolts. That's it. The distance between 6mm holes is 5 cm.

Taken Straight from the game, scaled, printed, assembled. Not exactly head-friendly, needed to be carved out after printing to be comfortable. Was fun to wear at conventions!

Also, the horns are actually from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:417014 . They did an excellent job with actually putting a texture to the helmet! I will probably be doing a Remix of theirs in the future.

Took from the Skyrim Gamefile models, scaled, printed.

I used White Gorilla Glue to put it together. It ended up being a good choice overall since it was perfect for sealing the gaps because it expands. Afterwards I just sanded down the whole thing with acetone and sandpaper. It ended up coming out decently rough looking, albeit a bit too shiny because of the paint.

comments.author: alenh

description.text: I DL'd the original file here but it was terrible and every piece needed to be re-modeled. I did the chore and this is the result. I've printed two now successfully. There are 52 pieces in all, grouped into 13 prints. This is intended as a static display model. It does not shoot anything. The only functionality is the bolt and spring do cycle and the clip is removable. I have plans to modify further so collapsible stock can open, but right now you have to choose when building it open or closed stock. I will add close up pics of finished model after I airbrush it.

In light of the comments left I have added the sliced .x3g files. They are for my dual extruder so some mods may be needed for your setup.
Recommended print settings (std. or Fine at your discretion.)
Print Group A: with supports 100% fill
Print Group B: 30% fill min.
Print Group C: with supports min. 30% fill
Print Group D: 3 shells with or without supports
Print Group E: no supports 30% fill min.
Print Group F: with supports 100% fill
Print Group G: no supports 30% fill .1mm layer
Print Group H: no supports 30%+ fill
Print Group I: with supports 30%+ fill
Print Group J: with supports 30%+ fill
Print Group K: 100% fill
Rail: with supports 50% fill
Tube: no supports 3 shells 30%+ fill

comments.author: Telli

comments.text: I know its not easy to build, I've done 3. That's why I have been working on "Mark II". I have re-designed almost everything improving the model. I've added tabs and holes for barrel alignment and thickened most parts to increase strength. Many other part alignment assists, Improved trigger group making trigger and safety switch functional, improved shot counter with better graphics, the collapsible stock is now functional (I'm proud of that one.) You can fold it or open it and no longer have to decide which configuration to build. I also added knurling to the grip like the original. Basically I turned it from a wall hanger to a CosPlay Prop. Just one thing. I'm also writing detailed instructions for assembly. I've spent a lot of hours on this re-design and I'm not distributing the files until I find a contest to enter. I need to try and recoup some benefit from all my work.

author: cmdrironman

title: 100 % Printable Castle composed by basic mold of sand

description.text:
This is a funny Sand Castle upped for the challange #BuildACastle .
Is made by simple mold of sand.
It has been designed according to a basic principle:
the maximum height that can reach a sand column without collapse is equal to the cube root of the square of the radius of its base.

We advise the instructions of printed divided in two Cura's sets.
Structure Sets:

INFILL
-Shell Tickness: 0.8 mm
-Top/bottom Thickness: 0.8 mm
-Infill overlap: 15%
-Infill pattern: Grid
Check infill top solid
check infill bottom solid

SUPPORT
-Support Pattern: Lines
-Overhang angle: 43°
-Fill density: 5%
-XY distance. 0.7 mm
-Z distance: 0.15 mm

SKIRT AND BRIM
-Skirt Line: 0
-skirt distance 2

Extrusion sets:
General
check enable retraction
check perimeter before
-Retraction speed: 40 mm/s
-Retraction distance: 4 mm
-Minimum shift before retraction :1.5 mm
-Minimum Extrusion before retraction: 0.1mm
-Z Hop: 0 mm
-Base object Cut off: 0 mm
-nozzle diameter: 0.4 mm
minimizes crossing parameters: Always

author: timope

title: E3Dv6 Hot End Fan Shroud for Printrbot

description.text:
Following the very traditional design of Printrbot fan shrouds, this one supports the E3Dv6 hot end perfectly as tested. The airflow is directed BELOW the heat block, allowing proper temperature regulation.

The original shrouds meant for the Ubis would direct air at the E3Dv6 heat block and I would lose 10 degrees Celcius, and the hot end would never reach optimal operating temperature if I set the fan beyond 50%.

With this, I can set my hot end fan at 100% resulting in very clean output, and surpassing the 50mm bridge torture test results I ever got with my Ubis.

It also stays out of the way of the hot end assembly (no risk of melting) and nozzle (for changes or unclog operations).

comments.text: Love this design but what is it attached to? What kind of e3d mount are you running? Links? I'd love to use it!

comments.text: v6 for the Printrbot. I've since upgraded the heat block to the sock model but this shroud still works, albeit a tighter fit.

A modified version of the battery holder from Mister Black (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33406). Edits include removing the AA section, elongating the AA section to hold 16 AA batteries, and shortening the model height down to 20mm to save plastic.

This model holds 16 AA batteries. I have test printed it and it turned out fine (Black ABS, XYZ Da Vinci Duo 2.0), though I would like to modify the model further to reinforce the structure of the long walls since they felt a bit flimsy and weak when I gave them a gentle pinch. Still, this test model does it's job.
The original model was downloaded from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33406 and then modified using Blender's boolean operations in junction with iterative copies of the original model upon itself.

History

The Riesenrad ("giant wheel" or Ferris Wheel) is one of Vienna's many beautiful and best known landmarks. It is located at the entrance of the amusement park "Prater" in Vienna's second district.

The wheel was built in 1897 and was the worlds tallest wheel till 1985 (Now it is the Cosmo Clock 21 in Yokohama). Originally the wheel had 30 gondolas, but in the second world war the wheel was severely damaged and only 15 gondolas were rebuild to keep the cost of maintenance low. Since then it is still operated that way.

The Riesenrad is 65m high and you can ride on it most of the year andoverlook at the beautiful city of Vienna. The Riesenrad moves with a whopping speed of 2,7 km/h and thus takes some time to ride. The whole construction weighs in at 430 tons.

Motivation

My motivation was to rebuild the giant wheel in such a way that it may easily adapted for a different sizes, that is why I chose to construct it in OpenScad.

Also, I wanted to design the wheel as near to the original as possible but with print-ability in mind.

I think that building the giant wheel at the time it was originally constructed was quite an accomplishment. A massive steel construction, that is round and moves, how could one not like and admire it?

Production times

Printing

  • Gondolas: The 15 gondolas with body and roof took about 6 hours to print.

  • Wheel: The complete wheel with the gondola holders and the wheels themselves took about 16 hours.

  • Stands: The two stands, front and back took about 12 hours.

A word about effective printing

I joined the challenge a week before the deadline and knew from the beginning that I will need to use time for printing effectively. The print times mentioned above do not account for prototypes I had to do for every part, just plain printing time of the parts.

After prototyping the single parts I arranged them in such a way that allowed me to print all or at least a considerable number of them together.

Before leaving home in the morning I started printing a batch which allowed me to do other things in the mean time. In the evening I used the time to quickly prototype the parts so I could do one or more batches overnight.

I use OctoPrint as my host software, which allowed me to send Push Bullet notifications when a print job is done.
I set an alarm for the notification coming from the printer to wake me up and remove the parts from the printing bed and start a new print job before going to bed again (or in my case the couch, since my girlfriend was not all too amused about waking up every couple of hours, and me coming back smelling like hairspray).

Painting

Each gondola took about 15 minutes which makes a sum of about 4 hours for all gondolas, not counting the dry time between each painting stage.

Assembly

Assembly took about 8 hours, the most time consuming part was lining the wheels which took about 3 hours, because you have to be very careful to align the wheels to the center.

Resources

  • Riesenrad on Wikipedia
  • Riesenrad homepage

Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GKYewbndmj4

Depending on how you want your wheel to be, to the printed parts you will need some additional materials. I will list the mandatory items first and the optional materials later.

Mandatory

  • An M8 Bolt, about 10cm long
  • 6 M8 nuts
  • Some strong string, for example twine or fishing line
  • Super glue or plastic glue, make sure that it will not dissolve your filament
  • Red and gray filament

Optional

If you want to apply a paint job you will need the following colours:

  • brown for the inside of the gondolas
  • white for the windows, doors and numbers on the gondolas
  • grey for the roof tops

If you want your wheel to turn you will need:

  • Two 608 bearings
  • A slow turning motor, I used the Igarashi 20G-380
  • Batteries to power the motor, 2 x AA Batteries give good speed to the above mentioned motor.
  • Battery holder to house your AA batteries. The only one I had available is for 3 x AA batteries, so I just shortened one battery space.

Printing and assembly

For the sake of time efficiency I suggest to print and assemble in the following order:

  1. Print 15 gondolas, printing them first gives you some time for painting while waiting for the other parts.
  2. Print 15 roofs
  3. Print 15 pod arms to attach the gondolas
  4. Print 15 free pod arms no gondolas will be mounted on those
  5. Print 10 ring segments, each ring consisting of 15 ring segments, in total, printing the mentioned file three times
  6. Assemble the rings. Start by taking a ring segment, insert one pod holder in the cutout, insert a free pod holder in the other cutout, close up with a ring segment, the fit is tight but you better glue it in.
    When you have 15 of those, assemble and glue to a full ring.
    I made the mistake of first building both rings, then sticking in all of the holders in one ring and then attaching the second ring on top, which made some of the ring segments break and I had to glue them again. Avoid my mistake!
  7. Print the top of the back stand, you will need to print this twice, once for each side.
  8. Print the bottom of the back stand
  9. Glue top and bottom of the stands together
  10. Print the top of the front stand, if you want to attach a motor you will need to print the top of the front stand with motor, otherwise just print the plain top twice.
  11. Print the bottom of the front stand twice
  12. Glue top and bottom of the front stands together
  13. Print the wheels center pieces
  14. Print the cross beams
  15. Now comes the tricky part, with your string you need to connect the rings to their center pieces. Do this slowly. Make the connection with a single string, so you can tension and move it a bit later on in case it is not centered perfectly.
  16. Mount the M8 screw with four nuts on the wheels center plates. Two from the inside and two from the outside. Make sure the center plates do not move on the screw, you may need to glue the center rings to the nuts, or tighten the nuts really well.
  17. Insert the bearings into the back stands, and attach them to the wheel, screw on the nuts from the outside.
  18. Glue the front stands to the back stands. In case you opted for the motorized version attach the coupling to the M8 screw and then to the motor, then glue the front stand to the back.
    Also print the motor wedge and glue it to the front top stand with the hole for the axle.
  19. Glue the cross beams between front and back stands
  20. Insert the gondolas into the gondola holder. Now you are done

I uploaded all of the parts as singles so in case not all parts of a batch come out as you would like them, eg. they warp, you can print them one by one until they all look good.

author: tinman160

description.text:
A chess board designed for (reasonably) easy printing and assembly using a hole-and-filament-peg method. Assembled board is 34 cm x 34 cm (13 x 13 inches). Designed especially to go with my OpenSCAD Chess set http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:585218

Update, August 22, 2015: Entered the chess set at the Montgomery County, Maryland Agricultural Fair under the category "Crafts: handmade toys and games", and won first place! Perhaps one day they will have a category "Crafts: 3D printed". . .

Print one piece base_plate_center and four copies each of base_plate_edge and base_plate_corner. Assemble by inserting 1.75mm filament into each hole on the side, and cutting it to a length of 2-3mm. The filament then becomes pegs to hold the base pieces together. Apply solvent glue and press the pieces together with a clamp. Assemble first into three separate rows, and then bond the rows together to make the completed board base.

Add filament pegs to all the holes on top, cutting the filament to a length of about 1-1.5mm. Keep the distance even by using a small allen wrench or toothpick to keep your wire cutters positioned at an exact and repeatable height above the board when you make each cut.

Print 64 pieces of board_tile, 32 each of two different colors. Put solvent glue on the backside of each tile, and place on the board, using a clamp or mallet to drive the tile down on the pegs.

The photos show the board printed with the base done in black PLA, and the tiles done in wood filament, stained and finished dark and light. To get the wood filament to look more like real wood, I printed all the tiles standing on edge, 8 to 16 at a time positioned close together in a row, looking like a heat sink. I printed on a raft to keep the tiles firmly attached to the bed while printing. Printing on edge makes the layers form a wood-grain pattern on the tile surface, with all the layers going in the same direction and no obvious 3D-printing artifacts like a crosshatch pattern or border showing on the surface. I needed to print two perimeters, or else the infill pattern shows through on the surface when stained.

Tiles were sanded thoroughly, then given two coats of stain, followed by a gloss coat, and finished by lightly sanding with fine steel wool. All finishing work on the tiles was done before final assembly.

This is my Astro A40 headset holder that i designed for my IKEA desk. This is designed to clip onto a desk with a 20mm height. This should also work for any headset, as the A40's have a larger than usual headband width.  
This was printed on a Rep 2, with a .25 layer height, and a 15%infill, 2 shells, and 230C. Took about 35 minutes to print. If you have any questions, feel free to ask.

After having some difficulties with the Plastruder MK3 which comes with the MakerBot, I decided to try to print a better (i.e. more reliable) extruder with and for my MakerBot.
The design was inspired by the \"Thermoplast Extruder Version 2.0\" from the RepRap project and by photos I saw of Nophead\'s \"Fast extruder\" .
(Update: There's now a 4th part to print: InsulatorRetainer.stl)

Please see http://wiki.makerbot.com/makerbot-127 for detailed build instructions. In addition to the 3 printed parts, you\'ll need:
  • Two 626 ball bearings.
  • Four M4 bolts, 60mm long
  • Four M4 nuts (optionally two of them as wingnuts)
  • One M6 bolt (30mm long)
  • One M6 nut
  • Three M3 bolts (30mm long)
  • 3 or more M6 washers
  • 3 or better more M3 washers
  • 4 M4 washers
    • new or canibalized from your current MK3 Plastruder:
  • 37mm DC motor with pulley
  • The \"heater section\" (i.e. thermal barrier, heater barrel, nozzle, and so on...)
  • Big and small dino (for mounting in a MakerBot)
  • Extruder driver electronics

comments.text: I just wanted to say. Thanks for this awesome design. It has only failed me once in a month, compared to the constant tinkering my MK3 needed. I am so glad I printed this before my mk3 died.

comments.text: ok, my origional extruder finaly bit the big one and i tried the printruder to no avail. the placement of the throughhole for the filiment was way to close to the gear and overloaded my motor without being able to move it at all. currently building a new one out of aluminum so i can try printing a new plastic one :)

Sorry for the problems.
As described in the build instructions ("Clean the parts up", http://wiki.makerbot.com/makerbot-127)http://wiki.makerbot.com/maker..., you should always check the diameters of all holes and re-drill them if necessary. Due to shrinking of ABS during the printing process, some of the hole might be smaller than they should be.

comments.text: So I just picked up 18 of these from my local maker space.   I'm going to assume their 3d printer (xyz davinci 1.0) just wasn't capable of printing them well.  The tile spaces work well, but the tabs are almost entirely different sizes or don't fit together.  The 3x3 works great by itself, but cannot lock them into other 3x3 pieces because of the tabs.  Trying to figure out a way around this which may involve cutting the tabs off and adding very thin magnetic tape or velcro to the sides.
comments.author: Soldiermedic

comments.text: I had a set of these made - first foray into 3D printing (via a 3d printing hub - no link, but the name is obvious...) - looks like it will resolve at least 90% of the annoyance some players have with the tiles not being perfectly aligned (now the complaint will probably be that the grids are moving against each other...
comments.author: hunnymonster

comments.text: Thanks for this alternative. I had mixed results with the other one's interlocking tabs. One batch from one company worked, but was expensive. The other batch from a more reasonable company required a lot of sanding. And I mean a lot of sanding. If these circular plugs work better, it's be fantastic. Since I do not have a printer myself, I'll try to farm it out to someone, and keep you informed how it goes. But again, thanks for the hard work on this. The grids that I have that work are fantastic, and make the gameplay so much nicer. No accidents.

description.text: UPDATED 5/30/2013 - Added optical tube extension rails, strengthened the "selfie cam" attachment point and improved the secondary mirror attachments. UPDATED 5/29/2013 - Added solar panels and fixed a few details to improve print quality. Inspired by today's launch of the Planetary Resources kickstarter, I created a 3D model of the Arkyd 100 spacecraft. http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1458134548/arkyd-a-space-telescope-for-everyone-0 The ARKYD 100 Space Telescope is Planetary Resourcesâ€™ first Arkyd Series 100 product. It will provide the company with the core spacecraft technologies necessary for asteroid prospecting while creating the first space telescope within reach of the private citizen. The ARKYD contains the critical structures, avionics, attitude determination and control, and instrumentation that enable low-cost asteroid exploration. The ARKYD 100 Space Telescope provides spectacular views of the Earthâ€™s surface and deep space, including the rich, virtually unexplored areas between our planet and the Sun. Central to its configuration and functionality is a precision imaging system. With arc-second resolution, the ARKYD 100 spacecraft camera will provide detailed celestial and Earth observations where you want them, and when you want them. The ARKYD 100 is capable of surveying for near-Earth asteroids during one orbit, then be retasked for rain forest observation on the next. The possibilities for utility and engagement are only limited by the imagination of the user. Planetary Resources is currently developing the ARKYD 100 Space Telescope for spaceflight in the near future, and is proud to have it as its first product offering to the public.

This is an untested printable X-Arm suitable for both Ormerod. Ormerod 1 users should use Extruder from the Ormerod 2.
This is a completely redrawn object consists of 2 printable parts. Part 2 is unfortunately a little bit too big so you may have to rotate this part by 45° to be able to print it. And at this part you may need support.
After printing simply slide the two tiles together and add a cap-head screw. I think a M3x12 could do this job.
Try to print this on a smooth surface and preferable in SmartABS. The part should be even. No warping is allowed.
The complete part is only for demonstration and not meant for printing as the most of you cannot print such large objects (and one screw hole would be useless).
After some print fails I think this can work really good. But I have to use another bed surface, so I only can get a structured surface. Does not look that nice but should do the job.

V1.3 - Part1: Holes of notches widen a little bit; Part2: Support for screw hole added. You can mix V1.2 and V1.3 according to your needs.

V1.2 - Notches changed - I hope this works now.

V1.1 - Small fix for the mounting of the Z-Runner (screw was not centered properly)

Hey all I'm building a custom drone, and using the AirGear 350 T-Motor kit for my motors and esc's and here is the motor mount. Also uploaded a 1mm spacer which may be used if needed. The opening is 20mm wide and 13mm tall. More info in Instructions.

Follow me for more drone parts in the future, Let me know of any questions i'll always help when I can. If you have exact dimensions of another motor and need a mount designed we can talk.

Made in blender, this is just the motor mount and 1mm spacer (optional) for the AirGear 350 T-Motor kit.

Print settings I used are 50% infill for extra strength, normal print settings and supports. Part weighs 12grams when printed with HIPS

Notes: A Small drill bit may be needed to clean out the screw holes because they are exact to these motors.

20mm Tall
34mm Wide
58mm Long

Opening
13mm Tall
20mm Wide

title: iPhone 5 Stand/Charging Dock with Flower Vase

description.text: This iPhone 5 charging dock will fit an iPhone 5 (with some space if it has a case) and hold water in the vase for flowers on your nightstand!

Built in SketchUp.  As you can see the original had words on the bottom so feel free to customize for yourself.  I made this specifically for a phone with a specific case to stand straight up (no lean), but this should fit most phones with cases and will have a little wiggle room if your phone has no case.  The stand will sit so the home button is still accessible and the charger will come up the back.  The pictures shown were version 1 while the files attached are version 2 (a bit wider stand)  
Let me know if you have any questions!

Inspired by (Matthew Croucher) 5mm Calibration Cube Steps

This model can be used for check:

  • dual color setup in general
  • bridge printing parameters
  • cooling system efficiency

General dual color test passed if printed model can't be disassembled by reasonable efforts to different color parts after print and borders between colors are smooth

Bridge test can be passed for both materials at the same time. This model depend on printing parameters if small or large bridge test enabled. You can set slicing layer height and horizontal extrusion wide in "Print parameters" Customizer tab. Bridge test deepening depends on printing parameters.

If your print cooling system is efficient top small cube will have sharp (90 degree) vertical edges.

P.S.
When both color parts displayed at the same time in OpenSCAD or Customizer some sides colors are not correct but colors parts suitable for printing. I am not sure is it my mistake or software bug.

title: octopi or astroprint logitech c170/c270 mount

description.text: I broke the original mount on my logitech c170 and needed a simple replacement. you can easily remove the original mount by running a hacksaw between the gap at the camera end at the end with the blanking plate. I have used a round magnet that is used to hang prices from a well known high street diy shop (B&Q) :-p If you ask the staff nicely they will give you one for free.

you need to print 10 link parts and 5 spacer parts and one base.

you will also need
5x m3 lock nuts
4x m3 washers
6x m3x35mm bolts
1x strong spring (from a clothes peg)
1x hex head m4 bolt as long as needed.
2x m4 nuts

author: nikki81

description.text:
Love playing card games or know someone that does? This makes a great gift for anyone with dexterity challenges, the elderly, as well as kids. Cardeasy helps hold and organize a hand full of cards and if you print one out for someone that has that problem, they will love you for it. I have included a nice stand so you can sit it down and still see the cards.   
You can find both the STLâ€™s and the original SolidWorks design files in case you wish to remix.  
Enjoy!

Nothing special. I printed this on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using medium makerware settings, 2 shells, 10% fill, and without support standing upright. Hopefully it will work as nicely on your printer.   
The gap is pretty tight and may have some burr from printing, which if not removed may scratch the cards. I used a utility knife to clean out the gap. Also consider running some fine sandpaper in the gap to smooth it out.

comments.text: Printed this for my daughter. It worked out of the box, with only once going with a blade through it, no sanding at all. I had printed this with a reduced flow rate of 96% (no idea, why, but it seems to have been the right thing to do). Support 20%, PLA. To me no noticable scratching of the card, although I have to admit we do like to use old playing cards, worn over the decades, and I'm not that picky.

Side print is not going to work.
Firstly the side is not flat so with or without support you would have a bad surface.
Secondly a sheet will not be stable and the plastic will not stick on it at all.

title: Auger-based feeder for animals, fish etc using Nema 17 stepper motor

description.text:
An auger-based feeder for a Nema 17 stepper motor. Feed your pets on a timer, in certain quantities or remote-controlled by adding a Raspberry Pi or Arduino. Perfect for a pet feeder, aquaponics system or related.

I printed all of this in PLA, I printed the Auger vertically. For the backside of the feeder unit, I used knurled brass threaded inserts with an outside diameter of 6mm. Here is a listing for some on eBay: http://www.smooth-on.com/Epoxy-Coatings-XTC/c1397_1429/index.html. I then melted them in with a soldering iron using this technique: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KUEFhiFB6Zs

Assembly for this is done by screwing the motor plate to the Nema 17 then attaching the auger to the stepper with a 3mm screw and a nut that is inserted into the bottom of the auger.. After the auger is attached to the stepper, insert the whole assembly into the feeder and attach using 4mm screws.

Feedback is always appreciated. Released through my company Northern Layers: http://northernlayers.com

Custom cookier designed by savd using CookieCaster: http://www.cookiecaster.com

Dimensions:
Longest Length: ~4.0 inches (10.2 cm)
Height: 0.65 inches (1.7 cm)
Thickness: 0.08 inches (2.0 mm)\n ( change dimensions at: http://cookiecaster.com/casts/13693 )

CookieCaster cookie cutters are easily printed on your MakerBot using the standard settings - we recommend using PLA to print and then saran wrap for cutting to make cleanup easy and to prevent any loose plastic from getting in your cookies
Built with 7 recursive layers.

This is a ring made from a hexagonal mesh torus. It's currently sized for a ring around size 10 or 10.5 (my left ring finger is size 10.5 and this doesn't quite fit, but it fits on my other ring finger). I made it by using this mathematica code:
http://mathematica.stackexchange.com/questions/39879/create-a-torus-with-a-hexagonal-mesh-for-3d-printing
and then I dropped it in Tinkercad and bored a cylinder hole out of it.

I'm going to keep iteratively tinkering with this design because (a) I'm not entirely satisfied with it yet and (b) I think I will get to learn lots of interesting things about (i) conformal mappings on the torus and (ii) stl files.
In particular, I don't love how it's divoted in on each hexagonal facet, and I think this is an artifact of how Mathematica exported the stl file. I suspect that fixing this problem will also fix the problem of the jaggies on the top/bottom of the ring.
Also it is kinda bulky right now.

The International Harvester S-Series is a medium and heavy-duty truck line that was manufactured by International Harvester. "S-Series" was first used as a label for the 1956 and 1957 Light Line trucks, until replaced by the A-series for 1958. The S-series label was reintroduced in mid-1977 as a replacement for the International Harvester Fleetstar. In 1979, other versions of the S-Series were introduced to succeed the Loadstar-series. Like the Loadstar, the S-Series were straight trucks commonly used for local delivery; the versions replacing the Fleetstar were semi-tractors or severe-service straight trucks. Additionally, the S-Series (and its replacement, the 3800) proved popular in the school bus industry. The S-Series was the last product line designed from the ground up by International Harvester themselves; it was produced in its original form until the end of the 1980s. Production of the second-generation S-Series ended in 2001.

A replacement tip for your beyblade collection. The kids were fighting and crying and wailing and gnashing their teeth today when I got home from work. It seems that the 5 year old had lost the 7 year old's beyblade tips. Out of 5 beyblades, only one was tipped. That's 80% tiplessness with a high misery index. Hopefully when they wake up, the peace of the family abode can be restored by this $0.10 print. But if not, well, I'll be heading off to work. :) I can't believe this thing worked the first time. It has all the retaining ledges and little clippy ridges and stuff. It fit the beyblade without much cleanup at all. OK, I guess I should have searched thingiverse first, here is a similar project. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8327 . I'll have to try his designs too and see if they work on the kids beyblades.

• Print

  • um, put it on the beyblade

  • Why are you still here?

  • If you print raftless like me and squash the bottom layer you may need to clean up the little squashed out parts on the bottom.

  • I print 4 at a time using the multiply feature in skeinforge so that I don't have to worry about cooling between layers.

  • I also use the zero extra shells trick as seen on Makerbot blog here
    • http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/03/18/super-sweet-printing-tech-zero-extra-shells/

  • I'm done talking now

  • OK, seriously now, go away!

  • I'm sure there will be pressure to design new and better tips, now that the first design is in their grubby little hands.

  • There that's an even ten instructions. That ought to be enough, right?

This window tilt latch is reversible to be used on the left or right side. It was created for my father who goes through about one of these every other month from the 3 properties he owns. They sell locally for about $5.00 but they are either not the right fit or always out of stock. Once these tilt latches fail, you can break the window if they are not replaced; I know because we have done it. With this file, we can have any window fixed in just over an hours time.

Use at your own risk, enjoy.

((uploaded a v2 of the 40mm fan back plate . now easier to install . first plug in all cables then slide new cover over wires. ))
(( i added a v2 of the radds display back.(v2 has a display bracket mount on both sides instead of one. to choose what side you like best ))
(( i added a display back for the radds display. i remixed from and you can download the rest of the display case here--
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:860709 ))

(( i added a new lcd back plate (for reprap controller)
remixed from and you can download the rest of the display case here--
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250 ))
(i added a ramps-fd box backplate with a 40mm fan for people that have 40mm fans.)

(i added a new thicker walled ramps-fd box for those that are having trouble printing out the original one)---(ramps-fd box thick.)

this is v1 of my ramps-fd enclosure with 30mm fan and eeprom hanger .
i am upgrading my duplicator i3 with ramps-fd
and am no longer using the stock psu.
updated with a spare 700w computer psu i had laying around.
that's why the box is just for the ramps-fd and display.
the display case is for a geetech Smart controller With LED turn on control 12864 Version.
the display and the box both have pivot points and uses gopro nuts and bolts.
for people with different smart controllers.
the display bracket is the same as a gopro base bracket. so you can also use a real gopro base with stickypad on the back of any display case you already have.

(NEED TO KNOW)
i designed this box for my ramps-fd that i slightly modified.
originally all the connectors are facing away from the board .and this is just annoying because the box needs to be really wide to plug in the connectors.

1.

you can either bend the connectors upward very carefully and slowly with a plug attached to keep all the pins lined up.

2.

if your good at soldering . you can de-solder the connectors cut the pins at the bend. keep enough to re solder into the holes on the board so all white connectors are facing upward.

and also created a Radds v1 enclosure for people that have Radds .

the Radds box has a mounting area on the back plate for a 30mm fan and a micro usb to usb-b adapter and the on off switch that comes with the duplicator i3 . but it still does not house the psu ..
i might make a different version to acomidate the psu. but not for now..

remixed_from.author: Aistaca
remixed_from.title: E3D v6 Adapter for Printrbot Simple Metal

title: Printrbot Simple Metal E3D v6 Hot End Secure Fit Spacer

description.text:
This is a remix of Aistaca's wonderful E3D v6 Printrbot Simple Metal adapter. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:559657)

Basically, you need a spacer to increase the length of the E3D v6 to make it compatible with the Printrbot Simple Metal.

I modified the height from 11mm to 7.2mm to allow for more metal on the E3D to fit in the extruder clamp. This is as high as you can mount the E3D without issues. Of course, you will also need to raise your probe, and you will need to change your fan shroud. I designed this one to work with the spacer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:964701

I also increased the depth of the 7.4 diameter inner hole. It was originally 2mm deep. Mine is 2.6mm deep. I found that the little black plastic ring that locks in the PTFE tube was taller than 2mm, which caused the spacer to not fit evenly. Now the spacer sits flush.

I also made the entire remainder of the inside diameter 4.4mm, so you can pass the PTFE tubing all the way up to the top of the spacer. If you cut the tubing short prematurely, just stack some on top.

Make sure the wider side of the heater block is facing forward, or else it will hit the back of the printer when calibrating. See picture for how I mounted mine.

Question: "My old Ubis hot end is broken. Can I temporarily mount the E3D v6 without the spacer, so I can print the spacer?"

Yes, that's exactly what I did! Just make sure that:

  1. Enough of the metal on the E3D is inside the extruder clamp for a secure fit.
  2. The PFTE tube goes all the way up to the extruder bottom. Be careful not to cut it too short! Cut long and keep trimming until you're there.

I don't recommend using it this way very long -- just enough to print a spacer.

Instructions:

Filastruder has a good price on the E3D v6: http://www.filastruder.com/products/all-metal-e3d-v6-hotend

ThisOldSpoon made a great E3D assembly guide here: http://thisoldspoon.blogspot.com.au/2015/03/e3d-v6-hotend-on-printrbot-simple-metal.html

You'll need new firmware with the proper thermistor settings. If you have a Printrboard RevD, you can use my modified firmware, available here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B3hjY10Eza2LZHNMUHVRZDRISk0

If you have a RevF Printrboard, use Aistaca's firmware, which he has made available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:559657/#instructions

Reflash your firmware using Printrbot's guide: http://help.printrbot.com/Guide/How+to+Reflash+Firmware/78

If your motors are acting funky, you probably need to invert some of your cables. See my picture to see how I had to orient mine in order to work (probably only applicable to RevD boards).

Be very careful when you're adjusting your z probe. You don't want it to grind into the bed. I would start with an initially high M212 Z height and carefully work your way to the ideal height. (For example, M212 Z5.00).

comments.text: Can you explain to me exactly why the new firmware is needed?
comments.author: WillSully

A iphone 4s case that features pi and a simple fractal using the beta version of MakeVR, which I get to test as an intern at sixense.

To make the pi symbol, I made some sweeps using the wire sweep tool  and laid the sweeps together on a cube's surface to make an impression that looks like pi. I was able to use this impression onto another cube to make a pi "stamp", which I then used to cut into the phone case (which was my template). The fractal was made by scaling a rectangular prism and gluing the components together.

title: CUBORG
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A modular organizer for the home or workshop. This contains the main cube, outer sides, dividers and drawers. It is modular so that addtional cubes can be added on the Top, Left, Right, Bottom sides and has mounting holes in the back side for mounting to a wall. The drawers have a label holder so items can easily be identified. Cube size is about 4x4.  
Download, print what you need and you can assemble a CUBORG of your own. Need more storage, print more and attach.

There is not really a lot to understand each box has the capability to attach to another box on the top, bottom, right or left side by inserting the pins into the holes and sliding it. It also has holes in the back for mounting to a wall surface.  A small set, however could be just as easily placed on a desk or counter without a fixed mounting to a wall surface.  
For a more finsihed look the downloads also include the covers again for the top, bottom, right or left and they fit in the same was a new box does, so it is configurable in an infinite amount of ways and with the covers looks very nice when all are put in place.   
The download also includes the vertical and horizontal dividers that you can print in any combonation to set up the boxes for the specific drawers you require for your CUBORG. Each size drawer is also included in the download for a possible 16 different drawer sizes ranging from 1x1 to 4x4 notice I do not say inch because the drawers are not matched to a specific inch. They are close to 1  equally 1 inch but not exact.  
Enjoy being assimilated into the organizational collective.

comments.text: What infill percent do you recommend? I have seen 33% suggested for a lot of things that need some strength but won't likely undergo structural stress. Also, do you go supportless? I have a Flashforge Creator Pro 2015, and have been having a hard time getting my bridging settings zeroed in, so I am worried about the connection hooks in the object.
comments.author: need2

comments.text: even more likely, if parts aren't coming out the right size, you have to set an outer layer offset, which accounts for how much the plastic "oozes" after it's laid down. if your parts are coming out oversize, but oversize by the same ammount in every dimension, then it's the offset parameter and not a scaling factor. if the scale is off, the parts will be slightly oversize in short dimensions, and lots more oversize in the longer dimensions

ESCs

With Escs you got 2 different options. If you choose the 4in1 Esc you won't need a pdb anymore since the 4in1 esc has a bec (5V voltage regulator) to power your flight controller.
If you use the slim escs from dys you have to add a PDB to add a voltage regulator and to distribute the power to the escs. Nowadays I would recommend to take the 4in1 it makes a cleaner build, reduces costs and also ist the newer option in terms of performance and software compatibility.

Radio Receiver

This is also just an overview. These are products that I have personal experience with and which I can recommend. There are tons of other transmitter and receivers out there but these are in a reasonable price range. I am personally flying the Flysky TH9X with the Frsky XJT module and am very pleased with the overall performance.

Thanks to everybody and happy flying.

comments.text: Hey Firefly, I can figure that you have built many of these copters and have tried multiple set-ups, what have you found to be the best overall setup? Like what motors/escs's/flight controller/etc.. Any help would be nice. Thanks
comments.author: Cullen99

comments.text:
See the parts list in the details for product links that I can recommend.
I'd use 1806 motors, an f3 or f4 flight controller and racerstar 4in1 20A esc for the power system.
The frame can only hold a small cam so get there fatshark 700tvl v2 and as a video transmitter I would choose one with at least 200mW. You can buy one of the cheap ones or get something more expensive which has benefits if you are flying with several people because they interfere less with the other 5.8ghz channels.
And thats it nothing more to a quadcopter in general.

comments.text: Since my last post, I have actually purchased a Vortex. I like it a lot although taking it apart can be a pain. I am considering printing the Firefly as a comparison and to fly together with some friends who do not own their own quad. I did have a few additional questions. First off, do you own a vortex? If yes, how does the 3D printed one compare? Furthermore, I assume you printed your version in ABS but I'm looking to print one in PLA (personal preference). Do you think the PLA will able to handle the temperature of the electronics, or would you strongly urge ABS use? And lastly, I can somewhat tell from the Guide on your website that you use the same T-navigator motors that the vortex uses, I assume you kept most of the other parts the same (?); If that's the case, do you think you could publish a part list (and I apologize if you already did but all I could find was the guide with instructions and screws required but no electronics). I know these questions are very specific so no worries if you can't answer them. Once again thank you for taking the initiative to make this model, I think it's absolutely awesome!
comments.author: Firefly1504

comments.text:
Nice to hear that you can call a Vortex your own. I personally don't own one I actually never seen one in person :D. The Firefly is a bit shorter then the Vortex and the screw diameters are different. The rest of the quad should be quite similar. Some parts are even interchangeable.
I choose abs for the fact that it is a little more forgiving when it comes to tolerances. The heat should be no problem in my opinion. Right now I am using a plan lower plate and all seems to be fine.
The motors I am using are
-dragonfly MC1806 2300KV,
-DYS BL20A ESCs,
-cc3d as flight controller charged up with beta flight
-and a really nice PDB with voltage alarm and many more features by Matek.
You are right I should finally make an electronics section on the website but I am really short on time in the last weeks.
If I can help you with links to the parts I used. send me a message. I hope I did answer all your questions.
Have fun flying and building !

comments.text: As I mentioned earlier. Get your printers set right. Right temperature so forth. Only print one motor mount part at a time. You print more then one at a time it will definitely make the parts brittle with no proper layer adhesion. I printed 4 at a time and they literally fell apart the moment I tried to bold them onto the other peaces. this is important for the lower part of the motor mount and the upper part of the motor mount. the plate and the stand are not worth mentioning.

comments.text:
I guess I can recommend some parts.
So as you might have figured out yourself it is a really small quadcopter so the electronics should be relatively small.
Get
4x 1806 motor I recommend Drangfly 1806 2300KV or any other with this specs
http://www.fpvmodel.com/dragonfly-mc1806-2300kv-mini-motor_g695.html
4x DYS SN20a these are very small and should work perfectly.
http://www.banggood.com/DYS-BL20A-Mini-20A-BLHeli-ESC-OPTO-2-4s-for-RC-Multicopter-p-975798.html
For the fight controller their are several options. CC3D, CC3D nano, Naze32 or any other in this size.
http://www.banggood.com/buy/flight-controller.html
For the FPV setup use the Fatshark 600TVL or better the 700TVL Fatshark cmos camera which has way better specs. You can also use another cmos camera in this size.
http://www.banggood.com/Fatshark-600TVL-CMOS-V1-Fixed-Mount-FPV-Camera-NTSC-PAL-p-917920.html
I used a 600mw mini 5.8ghz transmitter like this one.
http://www.banggood.com/5_8G-600mW-32CH-2s6s-DC-Image-Transmission-Q-Transmitter-For-Multicopter-FPV-p-984878.html
I had no space for a power distribution board. But you will need a bec if you are using ESCs without one inside.
http://www.banggood.com/3A-UBEC-Module-Low-Ripple-Bluesky-Mini-Switch-Mode-DC-BEC-5V-12V-2-6S-Supply-p-993056.html
I am using 1300mah lipos.

title: Threaded lens caps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Why do people worry about losing their lens caps when they are taking photos? Pocket technology has been around a long time. Rather, it's when the camera is in the bag you should be concerned about misplacing the lenscap. Squeeze style lens caps clip easily clip onto a lens when not in use, but on the other hand squeeze caps easily clip off when the lens is at your side or in a bag. Surely in this modern age we can do better? Hence the screw-on lens cap. They stay securely on when they should and can double as lens caps for two different sizes, which is great when out collecting photons with a main lens and an auxiliary. I even am confident enough to carry the camera in a rucksack.

I've printed these using Shapeways plastic sintering processes (Strong & Flexible Plastic) which does a good job of printing functional screw threads. Now I'm putting all my basic thread lens caps sizes here under a creative commons non-commercial attribution license (CC NC BY, with the aim of getting more of these active in the wild for field testing, and to test compatability with other printers, materials, and sizes I haven't tested. If you make and use one, please share your notes!

Read my notes on this and other projects (including some macro/micro-photography) at www.thebilder.wordpress.com or www.thescinder.com
Follow on Twitter @BilderStudios

Finally, if you don't have a printer at home, or just prefer an SLS version, check out my shapeways shoppe www.shapeways.com/shops/thebilder

Dan Kirshner's Screw Thread Modules were helpful for this project.
I've only used Shapeways selective plastic sintering for this so far, but printing these laid flat and with a thin layer height will probably give the best screw threads for an extruder printer.

author: Bazaff

description.text:
A dual fan mount for a stock Rigidbot. Independent ducts blow on the nozzle tips to avoid heater block temperature fluctuations. Requires no additional hardware to mount the ducts. Clears the bed by 2 mm and does not touch the rails.

Update: 12/17/2015 - I have functional Marlin firmware code for the Rigidbot that provides support for independent control of dual part cooling fans. For anyone interested just contact me and I can send you the firmware with instructions. There is no Slicer on the market that supports these features yet so the g-code still needs to be manually modified.

This is an original design. Modeling software used was trueSpace 6. The Source STL file will import directly into tS with the scene units in inches and the object units in mm. The Cura STL file is pre-scaled and oriented for printing.

Printing this will require support material to be turned on for best results. I printed this with a 0.1 mm layer resolution. It should print in under 6 hours. This resolution results in a very nice snug fit over the extruder mounting plate.

Only the one hex screw needs to be removed and will counter sink back into the hole to lock the fan mount in place.

comments.text: Update: 12/17/2015 - I have functional Marlin firmware code for the Rigidbot that provides support for independent control of dual part cooling fans.  For anyone interested just contact me and I can send you the firmware with instructions.  There is no Slicer on the market that supports these features yet so the g-code still needs to be manually modified.
comments.author: JP1

comments.text: TIP:  When mounting the fans you might need to put a little Teflon tape around the bar.  It will dampen any vibrations from fans that are not perfectly balanced.  Not all fans are manufactured equal.
comments.author: JP1

comments.text:
Can you describe, how to activate the second of these two fans? If i attach them to my rigidbot (first fan was powered by extruder 1, second one by extruder 2), then only the first fan starts. The second fan doesnt get power...
Or where did you wire the fans?
comments.author: goblingift

comments.text: The second fan pin (digital pin 11) is not officially supported by Marlin firmware so the fan will not turn on.  I worked with Rigidbot to get a firmware patch to activate it and test out independent control of the fans. It is a rough patch but it works.  An official patch has not been released. I don't think anyone has pushed dual head cooling fan control this far for the Rigidbot.  For my initial testing I switched the main cable between the heads to allow the second head to behave as the first.  I know this doesn't help when needing to print dual materials with independent fans at the moment.  I'll message you with more information.
comments.author: goblingift

comments.text: This fan nozzle configuration greatly enhances my bridging and overhang distances.  Just successfully completed a 15mm bridge and 4 mm overhang.  The outer tip on the first layer of the overhang requires a little clean up but the following layers came out flat.

title: Small Plant Pot with Water container

description.text:
For the new pot see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2307984 or click remixes.

This planter was inspired by the Self watering planter of Metaldrgn. Due to my small print bed reducing the Self watering planter caused the sides to be too thin. I designed this model in openScad to fit my printer in two separate parts, I have not test printed it yet, the two parts may need to be glued together to stop the inner pot from floating? I have also included the model as a whole ,if supports are used it may be tricky to remove them? The idea is to put a wicking material in the base of the inner pot up until the side holes, then place the soil and a small plant. The outer pot will provide self watering for the plant, if the plant is watered from above the side holes will drain excess water preventing the roots from drowning. I hope this is of use, it's my first model, so I'm sure many improvements can be made,

description.text:

A plug for the hole that the umbilical passes through. You will need to remove the shiny black plastic cover that is held in place with two 3mm screws.

It's a very tight fit, and I had a heck of a time with the small overhangs, so please leave your feedback if it doesn't fit for you. Be careful of course. If you break something, not my fault. :)

v4 has 2mm wide tabs.
v5 has 1mm wide tabs around the top and 2mm wide tabs around the bottom.

This is a remix of the wundel's model, which was sadly not printable. I have optimized the model for 3D Printing, scaled it down, sliced it up in to pieces and separated the armor into different STLs.

The wings on the original model were a bit cumbersome, so I took the liberty of removing them and I think the model looks better for it. It will also print easier without the wings.

Perfect for D&D games, this demon is ready to tear out some souls!

Recommendations for printing are in "Instructions".

If you print, please post a picture! Especially if you paint it!

Tips:

Print all parts with support with the lowest layer height and generally finest settings you can get away with.

Print two of the 'head' files at the same time with the spikes pointing up, this will make it so that the spikes will have time to cool before the next layer.

Print 'torso' with the hands pointed upward.

Print 'legs' mostly on its back with the front of the demon pointing generally upward, this will reduce the amount of support material needed and aid in removing it.

Print two of the 'shoulder armor' files, orient so that the detailed part is not facing down.

Print one each of 'lower armor' and orient so that the top of the armor is not facing downward.

Enjoy!

title: Servo driven nozzle wiper arm for delta printers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like having a dump area on my 3D printers so they can prime the extruder, wipe the tip on its way to the print surface and immediately start printing without all the extra hairs and globs. Worked great for my modified bukobot but on a delta you can't just have a longer axis to prime it off the table. This was my quick and dirty solution.

http://youtu.be/GJjhfp9_WCU

http://3dprint.com/87898/3d-printer-hacks/

You will need to print 2 servo mounts, 1 arm and 1 clamp.

You will also need a standard size hobby servo. I used a Hitec 31311S HS-311 as its pretty universal and around $10 USD. I would recommend using the same one as the arm is made for the servo horn to snap into; I didn't even use glue on mine. If you have a wide selection of servo horns laying around print the arm and see if you have one that fits and then use another servo. Otherwise, hey it's only $10....

You will also need some M3 hardware and T-nuts for mounting it to the extrusions.

Last but probably the most important, you will need a piece of material to use as a wiper. In the video I was using a piece of folded up PET tape. While it works, the better material to use would be a piece of high temperature silicon mat, similar to what is used on nice kitchen spatulas.

After you have it installed you will need to set it all up. I have attached my starting g-code. DO NOT use it as-is. It is just an example and you will have to modify all of the positions and servo angles to fit your printer. Set the height of the Z so that it is higher than the plastic printed arm but lower than the silicon wiper blade.

Print 4x the rod table mount.
Holes fit M3 Screws, but can be drilled to any bigger size if needed.
Make sure that you have no tension on the rods for the bed, otherwise it effects the prints negatively.
The tensioner for the belt is the original one.

I needed to strap some cables on the door of a cabinet. The cabinet door has a series 6000 unistrut strip mounted and I already had some cable ties with a mounting hole. I needed a nut and there is no local source. Therefore this is what I designed. I designed it in Design Spark and used a small wood screw to clamp the 2 halves together and this holds it to the strut. It may not fit your strut but it may give you an idea on a way to do it.
